1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-CalARP program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Mar Vista Resources has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-CalARP related activities. 



1.1 Mar Vista Resources, Risk Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Mar Vista Resources has updated their unified RMP-CalARP Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                              | Process Chemical                   | Process Quantity

24.5% Aqueous Ammonia Blending Process      24.5% Aqueous Ammonia                220,000 lbs.





Our RMP-CalARP program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program to meet CalARP and RMP obligations

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software t

o ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-CalARP program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Mar Vista Resources operates a fertilizer manufacturing facility in Corcoran, CA. The facility utilizes 24.5% aqueous ammonia solution for manufacturing various nitrogenous fertilizers. 



24.5% aqueous ammonia solution is stored within two (2) 15,000 gallon double wall steel tanks. As required, 24.5% aqueous ammonia is pumped through fused polyethylene pipes into Mixer 5 and Mixer 6 where it is blended with other products to generate the desired fertilizer blend.





The process at Mar Vista Resources consists of tanks, mixers, pumps, and valves which are interconnected by piping.

 

The process is not subject to California or Federal OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation because the solution concentrations is less than the concentrations listed in the PSM regulation:



The 24.5% aqueous ammonia solution process exceeds the USEPA Risk Management Program (RMP) threshold quantity (20,000 lbs for ammonia solutions >20%). In the USEPA RMP Regulation, Table 1 to ?68.130 lists two different thresholds for ammonia: (1) Ammonia (anhydrous) over 10,000 lbs. and (2) Ammonia (concentration 20% or greater) over 20,000 lbs. Due to this distinction, when determining applicability for the USEPA RMP, the aqueous ammonia solution is calculated based on the total weight of the aqueous ammonia solution, rather than extracting the weight of the ammonia from the aqueous ammonia solution.



Additionally, the mass of ammonia within the solution exceeds the threshold quantity for the CalARP regulation (500 lbs).



RAGAGEP Statement

It is unknown which codes and standards were followed in the design and construction of the 24.5% aqueous ammonia solution process at Mar Vista Resources. In the future, Mar Vista R

esources will adhere to the most current version of the California Fire Code (CFC) when making modifications to the process. The applicable subsections of the 2016 CFC are listed below:

2016 California Fire Code ?5001 Hazardous Materials - General

2016 California Fire Code ?5003 Hazardous Materials - General Requirements

2016 California Fire Code ?5004 Hazardous Materials - Storage

2016 California Fire Code ?5005 Hazardous Materials - Use, Dispensing, and Handling

2016 California Fire Code ?5404 Corrosive Materials - Storage

2016 California Fire Code ?5405 Corrosive Materials - Use



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of the covered chemicals in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Mar Vista Resources has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for each process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 24.5% Aqueous Ammonia



The 24.5% aqueous ammonia blending process at the Mar Vista Resources facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 220,000 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an aqueous ammonia leak.



Our personnel monitor the aqueous ammonia blending process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that 

pertain to aqueous ammonia.



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Mar Vista Resources has had no accidental release within the l

ast five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Mar Vista Resources' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Mar Vista Resources has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Mar Vista Resources continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-CalARP program. This has improved Mar Vista Resources' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-CalARP related events so that Mar Vista Resources' management team can ensure that the RMP-CalARP program is being i

mplemented.



Mar Vista Resources has implemented all aspects of the RMP-CalARP program. When a RMP-CalARP program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Mar Vista Resources has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-CalARP program implementation.



For the future, Mar Vista Resources now thinks of the RMP-CalARP program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Mar Vista Resources employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-CalARP program Mar Vista Resources will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.\
